text: hello I'm Mary Rudder from the Harvey
Ken School in Charles Town and I teach
kindergarten um I use the Star Festival
CD ROM as part of our unit on Japan and
places in the world i also use it as a
connection between family life um family
roots and just to make the adventure
more real we start our adventure on our
airplane which the kids painted and
designed and then we prepare for our
trip by packing our suitcases which of
course are made of paper since
kindergarten is the paper capital of the
world um inside the suitcase is a plain
piece of white paper and the children
are asked to draw the things that they
think they will need on their trip and
sometimes you get what they would need
some children want to bring all the toys
they own and one of the boys this year
wanted to bring an ice cream machine
unfortunately when he went through
customs in Japan they would not let him
in they made him take it out of his
suitcase cuz I am the customs official
um after we prepare we also
have our airline tickets and since we
will be traveling to several places on
the earth on the world um there are
several categories that it lists the
places we we will be going tokyo is our
first stop although our trip will bring
us all the way to Haratska which is
where the star festival takes place um
the children have a ticket in their
boarding pass and quite a few children
real understand what a boarding pass is
so when they receive this they thought
the trip was almost real a few of the
children went home and said I'm going to
Japan tomorrow but you don't need to
worry mom cuz I'm going to be home by
8:00 tonight so I also issued them a
passport put their picture in it had
them sign their name checked to see if
they knew their address because this is
an important fact u fact toy the
kindergarten children are expected to
learn a few didn't know went home and
found out their birth date again a few
didn't know left a space on the back for
the stamps for when they go through
customs so as you can see we are in
Japan so in the afternoon because it's
an 18-hour flight from
Boston we board the ship we board the
airship just before we're leaving and
for the day and I collect their tickets
and their suitcases and stow them under
board and behind the airplane is seats
and they sit in
rows just as they would in a airplane
and they say "Oh uh when are we going to
be in Japan?" And I I will tell them
"You have to go home tonight go to bed
in your own bed and when you come back
in the morning we will be almost in
Japan so they come in the following
morning and when they came in the
Japanese house is up so we'll talk about
that in a few minutes before we start
our trip I want the children to know
where in the world they are and where
they've come from so we make a big mural
map which they help paint of course you
will notice that some of the continents
aren't quite correct because when they
get the paint in their hand they tend to
start painting areas that should be
water and end up to be land and land
that should be water or land that ends
up to be water so but it has a general
feeling for it and I send home a
questionnaire asking the parents because
most of the children in the class come
from other countries in fact just about
everybody in America comes from another
country if you trace back far enough and
they are asked just to write the child's
name and if you have I mentioned mom dad
grandparents what countries they come
from and when they come in I've already
used the same pictures that we have on
the passports to make a little um card
which will mount on our map with a line
that will go from the girl's name or
boy's name to Boston to wherever they
came from so the children will actually
be able to see where in the world their
family came from and it's quite
interesting and they become very proud
in fact the parents came in when they
saw the map up and said "Oh this is
where I come from this is so they didn't
know I was going to ask them the
question." So they'll I think they'll
really be thrilled when they see their
kids up with the name connected i think
it's just important because it gives
them a sense of you know where where
they came from and it also sort of gives
value to their background it was
interesting that I sent home because we
will be doing this paper um and we will
be doing a family tree but I didn't ask
for a family tree one of the kids came
back with it all written on the back of
the paper so I thought this is perfect
because when we start looking at
Shagaru's family tree and we start doing
our own here Juan has his all done only
we'll probably do it on a bigger piece
of drawing paper so you can see it and
I'll have him script the words so I
think that um it's interesting the
things you come out with and the things
that come out of the study
um
because um I want to go to Haratzka
because part of our adventure in Japan
is the big festival and what we will be
doing as we travel with Shagarro through
the different points going to the um
train station or from the train station
on the bus looking to see how it's the
same as what they're used to or how it's
different from what they know they were
thrilled to see the subway station the
train station because they noticed right
away it didn't look like a train station
that they are familiar with and um they
could see the little shops in the
background so they were "Wow that's
really pretty." So I think that's um
interesting that now they're thinking of
what they know and they're learning
something different um going to bring
you over to our house
and the bell's going
to I should sit on the floor but I won't
cuz I'll never get up
again um this is
Haruku and she's named after a little
girl I met in Japan when I went on a
visit and so when I came back I thought
kids like to relate to other kids um and
before I introduce Shagaru on the
um
CD uh Heruku introduces her
grandmother's house because I don't want
the children thinking that the every
child in Japan lives in a house that's a
traditional Japanese style house that
most of the children when they talk to
them would probably live in an apartment
u but they might they would probably
have a tatami mat on the floor and they
might have the kadatu um at their table
or they might have a western table so I
think it's important that they know some
of the things that um the the children
in Japan are doing now in fact we have
Japanese eels which is really a great
great deal of fun they're first graders
but they uh are kind enough to write to
us i show um Haku Haku in her regular
clothes but I have this little angel
that was sitting up here and the kids
all said "What is that what is that?"
And then they said "She has wings she
has wings." So I said "Oh what do you
think this is?" And they recognized
right away she's an angel and I said
"Why would I want to have her around?"
And oh she's good luck and I said "But
what's she wearing?" And we talked about
she has the kimono on and she has the
Gita shoes so it's sort of like a a tie
between the old and the the new and I
think the CD ROM does that a lot when
you see the older pictures and um you
know the festival dress uh you know I
think it's important for them to
recognize it um I tie in a lot of
literature and I introduced the story by
saying it's her
favorite so they think this is great if
she liked this story and they sit with
her after the story is read and um we'll
reread it or go through the pages
together or they'll all sit around the
table and try to oh look at the pictures
and talk to her they were we had our
friends in and we were singing songs
together and they were making her hands
clap because they wanted her to you know
while we're doing we're clapping they
wanted her to clap so they were like
really including her as part of the
classroom i think it's important for the
children to really become involved in
things to make it important to them
um we and I told them today they noticed
the festival decorations on the uh
opening screen and on some of the
pictures that they saw and they said "Oh
look at that." Uh especially the dragon
look at the dragon i said "Oh that's
part of the festival." And we're
traveling on this train to go to
Haratska because we're going to be part
of the festival and we will plan at the
end of uh two weeks of reading stories
about Japan true and mostly folk a lot
of folk tales they are it allows them to
process the story tell what it's about
they pick out their favorite part they
read it and um they thrilled me today
they read they they read the um wise old
woman and it sort of teaches why um the
it's so important to respect elderly and
they took their favorite part and then
they all stood and they started to write
all the they're sounding out their words
which is we're doing writers workshop so
this is like a big thing i was so proud
of them and they're going "Oh I got
this." And they could read it so I think
it's um you know even though we're doing
Japan we're still doing language arts
we're still doing writing
so um I try to keep that connection and
keep it tied in so I told them that the
festival we will be having a festival
and we will need to do all the
decorations just like they see in the
movie and um or film and that we will be
inviting our pals down the hall to come
in and partake of all the festivities
and I said um because I knew I didn't
want to have five kindergarten groups
all in here at once i said you know it
takes a few days so we'll probably have
it several days with one class in you
know each sitting so they were oh okay
we're ready so I think they're u I think
this is really going to be a great
adventure all the past years I've done
it it's been a learning experience for
the children and for myself they always
find a new angle or a different part to
um key in on and this especially this
class I think they're really keyed in on
just they really think they're there
they're really and I think that hearing
the noises seeing the sights going on
the bus ride seeing the fish market i
have to tell you the fish market the
girls saw the fish market one girl goes
"I love fish sticks." And so I'm like
"They're cutting the fish up into big
sections." I said "Oh that's nice well
you'll see all the fish later." And she
goes "I love." And I said "Well this is
where it comes from this is what happens
before it's made into fish sticks." So
here we'll be talking about how food
comes to the table you know what happens
it doesn't just materialize into fish
sticks we didn't just go out to the
river and pull up the fish sticks so I
think it's important for um you know to
see that we need food people in Japan
need food people in China need food we
basically are all different but we all
have the same kinds of needs so
um I don't know it's an
adventure want to see the old picture
this is a class I had that even at the
very end of the
day they were trying to
work because I totally identified
with Chagarro on the uh film and they
were looking at it and even when they
were had their coat on and they're
waiting for their parents to take them
home they would still go and explore in
different parts of the um computer
do I have a minute to tell you about the
book sorry I'm so
hot this is a project I was involved in
it's a real I mean really adventure and
so um this is the story of Shagira when
he was in Japan because the story on the
CD ROM is when he's grown up so this
takes all the information from the CD
ROM and makes it into a story
that a teacher or a parent or librarian
could read to the children and it shows
real pictures and it also shows
beautiful drawings and I think that um
just it it's a story that about his
family before he left and sort of how he
had a very happy joy joyful life with
his family and he's after it shows them
all the things he does with his going to
the
shrine fishing with his grandfather
um visiting his grandfather's shoe shop
things that were just an intricral part
of his life going to the model shop and
then to
have you know when he's nine or 10 to be
taken from his home roots and just
brought over into a very strange world
where he didn't speak the language and
he didn't you know really understand or
know any of the culture because he
wasn't exposed to it and then to have to
deal with that um and how he quickly
became more Americanized that after a
short or a year or so when
um he found out that a letter he had
sent to his grandfather was totally in
in English and his grandfather couldn't
read it and he didn't hadn't even
realized that he had done that so um I
think it a lot of the children I have
bilingual children and a lot of them
have um you know two languages or even
three languages and I think this sort of
really they understand that maybe
sometimes I say things to them they
don't quite understand what it is
because it's not familiar to them but
this sort of connects to their own their
own life and I think that when you see
Shagarro going back into Haratska and
visiting the old haunts that he went to
and looking at the old photographs you
can see um you know how much he changed
and how much he grew and how he would
have that feeling he's not quite sure
which culture he belongs to and maybe
that's how a lot of our children feel
